xwikidoc.title: IRC Archive for channel #medsavant on 17 June 2013
xwikidoc.content: <sdumitriu> has joined #medsavant 09:29 <sdumitriu1> has joined #medsavant 17:12 <bvancea> has joined #medsavant 17:14 <sdumitriu> Hey bvancea 17:15 <bvancea> hello sdumitriu :) 17:15 <bvancea> what's up? 17:16 <sdumitriu> SCO 17:16 <bvancea> what is SCO? 17:16 <sdumitriu> The dead company that's been insisting for the past 20 years that it owns Linux 17:17 <bvancea> =))))) 17:17 <sdumitriu> http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/SCO-Linux_controversies 17:19 <bvancea> haha 17:19 <bvancea> although 17:19 <bvancea> why do these companies claim ownership over Linux? 17:19 <sdumitriu> Which ones? 17:19 <sdumitriu> SCO? 17:19 <bvancea> Red Hat, Novell, IBM 17:20 <bvancea> and SCO 17:20 <sdumitriu> Well, they don't 17:20 <sdumitriu> SCO claims that it owns a UNIX variant, and that some Linux code copied code from that variant 17:20 <sdumitriu> In truth the UNIX variant they got was just the right to use, not the full copyright 17:20 <bvancea> yeah, you're right 17:21 <bvancea> I miss-read the first time 17:21 <bvancea> even so, there was so much development on the linux kernel 17:21 <sdumitriu> And the few lines of code that were similar both in Linux and in their UNIX was coming from an earlier kernel that is in the public domain 17:21 <sdumitriu> So they both copied from the same (open) source 17:21 <bvancea> haha 17:22 <sdumitriu> Well, that's the public part 17:23 <sdumitriu> The secret is that SCO is being funded by enemies of Linux to spread FUD about Linux 17:23 <sdumitriu> Of course, there's no real proof for that 17:23 <bvancea> interesting 17:23 <bvancea> well, tbh, Linux grew so much these last few years 17:24 <bvancea> I think it's really hard to make people lose their interest 17:24 <sdumitriu> SCO didn't produce anything, it went bankrupt a few times, and all it lives on is the hope that at some point they're going to win this trial and get a few billions back from IBM, RedHat and Novell 17:24 <sdumitriu> True 17:24 <sdumitriu> But MS never stops 17:24 <bvancea> so SCO is like those twins that keep suing Zuckerberg 17:24 <sdumitriu> Yeah, something like that 17:25 <bvancea> yeah, MS has some really ugly negative publicity tactics 17:25 <bvancea> like the Scroogled campain 17:25 <sdumitriu> Get The Facts 17:26 <sdumitriu> Or the fact that GMail is evil because it's reading your email, when in fact at some point the HotMail terms of use stated that MS owns your emails and can do whatever with it, not you 17:27 <sdumitriu> Anyway, the coding period is officially started 17:27 <sdumitriu> What are your plans for this week? 17:27 <bvancea> yeah :D 17:27 <bvancea> I'm writing my status email now :) 17:28 <bvancea> I'm thinking I could keep indexing variants 17:28 <bvancea> and continue testing 17:28 <bvancea> and in parallel check to see how another entity can be indexed 17:28 <bvancea> or refactor my code 17:29 <bvancea> not sure if you have something in mind that I could do 17:31 <bvancea> also, would it be ok if we set some sort of a milestone for the end of the first part of the coding period? 17:31 <sdumitriu> Sure 17:32 <sdumitriu> We'll discuss that at the call on Thursday 17:32 <sdumitriu> (thursday was it?) 17:32 <bvancea> ah, cool 17:32 <bvancea> I'm pretty sure its thursday 17:32 <bvancea> we didn't set a time for it yet 17:35 <bvancea> okay so, what should I set as a target for this week? a schema for the genes or some refactoring? 17:36 <bvancea> eh, I think both could be viable 17:37 <bvancea> I'll prepare some sort of a weekly plan for the first part of the coding then. So we can have it as a base for discussion on Thursday 17:38 <sdumitriu> I'd say refactoring 17:38 <bvancea> hmm 17:38 <bvancea> okay 17:40 <bvancea> also, how should we do about the code reviews? 17:41 <bvancea> I mean, if the features aren't yet integrated in medsavant 17:41 <bvancea> I'm guessing pull requests aren't quite ok for that 17:44 <sdumitriu> Well, there are two ways 17:45 <sdumitriu> One is to grant you commit access to the official repo, and you commit in a branch 17:46 <sdumitriu> The second is to commit on your fork and to make pull requests into a feature branch whenever you're in a stable state 17:46 <sdumitriu> I think the first one is OK, since there aren't that many committers on MedSavant to be picky 17:46 <bvancea> well, I've commited twice on my fork so far 17:47 <bvancea> and I'm still refactoring some code, but it seems to me it'll be increasingly harder for you to review 17:47 <bvancea> if I have many commits 17:57 <sdumitriu> The more, the better 17:57 <sdumitriu> Many and small 17:57 <bvancea> and, I see 17:57 <bvancea> ok 17:58 <bvancea> btw, have you worked a lot with Solr clusters? 17:58 <sdumitriu> Nope 17:58 <bvancea> ;)) 17:58 <bvancea> I've only made a real one for my diploma project 17:59 <bvancea> and indexing seems to get slower 17:59 <bvancea> the bigger the cluster 18:02 <bvancea> I watched a few videos about SolrCloud this weekend 18:02 <bvancea> and I was thinking that maybe we could try sending documents to more nodes, in parallel 18:03 <bvancea> but that might confuze the cluster and make it even slower 18:44 <bvancea> good night
